title: R44791
content: The funding authorization for the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is set to expire on March 31, 2018. FAA authorization acts typically set policy on civil aviation issues. Most FAA programs are financed through the Airport and Airway Trust Fund (AATF). The Airport and Airway Trust Fund (AATF) was established in 1970 to expand the nation's airports and air traffic system. It provides the majority of FAA's annual funding through various revenue sources such as passenger ticket taxes, air cargo fees, and fuel taxes. In 2016, the AATF had revenues of over $14.4 billion and a cash balance of more than $14 billion. The Airport and Airway Trust Fund (AATF) had a cash balance of over $14 billion in 2016, with an uncommitted balance of around $5.7 billion. Despite a recent growth in revenue and a projected increase in the near term, concerns remain about the fund's long-term sustainability due to reductions in general fund appropriations to the FAA and changes in airline business practices affecting AATF revenue. Airlines increasingly impose fees for various options and amenities, like checked bags and onboard meals, separate from the base ticket price. These fees are not subject to federal excise taxes, resulting in over $4.17 billion in baggage fees alone in 2016. General aviation operators, particularly corporate jets, are debated to contribute more to the trust fund. Proposals to increase general aviation jet fuel tax were not adopted in 2012. In recent years, FAA funding has totaled between $15 billion and $16 billion annually, divided among four main accounts. Operations and Maintenance (O&M) receives the largest portion of the budget, funding air traffic operations and aviation safety programs. The Airport Improvement Program (AIP) provides federal grants for projects like runway construction and noise mitigation. No proposals for per-flight user charges have been enacted into law. The Facilities and Equipment (F&E) account funds air traffic facilities and equipment acquisition and maintenance, research on aviation safety and efficiency, and environmental impact reduction. The federal government supports airport infrastructure development through federal grants for capital projects like runways and taxiways, and allows airports to assess a local passenger facility charge (PFC). Congress has authorized airports to assess a local passenger facility charge (PFC) on each boarding passenger, which can be used for a broader range of projects than AIP funds. Investors receive preferential income tax treatment on interest income from bonds issued for airport improvements. Airports may also use state and local funds, operating revenues, and different funding sources to finance projects, with small airports more dependent on AIP grants and larger airports more likely to issue tax-exempt bonds. In a 2007 study, GAO found that bonds financed 50% of airports' capital spending, AIP 29%, PFCs 17%, state and local contributions 4%, and airport revenue 4%. The assessment of airport capital needs is crucial for determining federal support to maintain a safe and efficient national airport system amidst bankruptcies and mergers in the U.S. passenger airline industry. Since 2000, major airline mergers have led to a reduction in commercial flights. Carriers have consolidated operations, flying fuller planes with an average load factor of nearly 85% in 2017. The FAA and ACI-NA have projected airports' long-term financial needs, estimating a total of $32.5 billion for FY2017-FY2021. Bonds, AIP, PFCs, state, and local contributions finance airport capital spending. This assessment is crucial for federal support amidst industry bankruptcies and mergers. The FAA and ACI-NA have projected airports' long-term financial needs, estimating a total of $32.5 billion for FY2017-FY2021. The ACI-NA survey resulted in an estimate of $99.9 billion over the same years, with differing views on airport projects to include. The FAA study included designated airports based on aviation activity forecasts and AIP grants, while the ACI-NA study cast a wider net, including projects funded by PFCs, bonds, or state/local funding. The ACI-NA estimate of airport capital needs is significantly higher than the FAA estimate, including security projects funded by airports or TSA, AIP-ineligible projects, and AIP-eligible projects not requesting funding. FAA focuses on evaluating capital needs at major airports, with studies like FACT3 showing improved reliability and reduced congestion in the air traffic system. The study found that while NextGen is helping to manage delays caused by airport congestion, new capacity and other solutions are still necessary to address traffic growth and reduce delays at some of the largest and busiest airports. Capacity constraints across the aviation system may not be as dire as in previous analyses, but several of the busiest airports would continue to be capacity-constrained in the near term. The AIP provides federal grants to airports for airport development and planning, ranging from large commercial airports to small general aviation airports. The AIP provides federal grants to small general aviation airports for construction of improvements related to aircraft operations. Commercial revenue-producing facilities are not eligible for AIP funding. AIP funds distribution reflects congressional priorities for airport safety, security, capacity, congestion reduction, noise and environmental mitigation, and financing small state and community airports. AIP grants can provide funds for capital projects without the financial burden of debt financing, with airports required to provide a modest local match. The AIP program provides federal grants for small general aviation airports to fund projects listed in the National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems (NPIAS). Funding levels have fluctuated over the years, with gaps between authorized spending and actual expenditures. The AIP program's funding levels have varied over the years, with increases in authorization starting in FY2001. Funding peaked at $3.47 billion in FY2008 and was authorized at $3.35 billion annually through FY2017. The distribution system for AIP grants is complex, involving formula grants and discretionary funds. The AIP program distributes funds through formula grants and discretionary funds to specific airports. Entitlements are apportioned by formula and can be used for various airport projects. Different categories of airports receive funds through different formulas, and most airports have up to three years to use their apportionments. The AIP program distributes funds through formula grants to specific airports based on passenger boardings. Non-hub commercial service airports have up to four years to use their apportionments. The apportionment for primary airports is based on the number of boardings, with a minimum allocation of $1 million. The AIP program allocates funds based on passenger boardings, with a minimum allocation of $1 million for primary airports. Cargo service airports receive 3.5% of funds, while general aviation airports receive 20%. Remaining funds are distributed based on a state-based population and area formula. The FAA makes project decisions. The FAA controls the distribution of funds for airport projects based on a state-based formula. Some states see these funds as an opportunity to address general aviation needs statewide. Alaska receives supplemental funds to ensure airports receive double the funding compared to 1980. Large and medium hub airports forgo a portion of their AIP formula entitlements if they collect a passenger facility charge of $3 or less. Small airports can receive discretionary grants from a special fund. The discretionary fund receives 87.5% of forgone funds from small airports, while the remaining 12.5% goes to a separate discretionary fund. FAA approves discretionary grants based on project priority and other criteria. At least 35% of discretionary funds are set aside for noise compatibility planning and abatement. Funds are allocated for noise compatibility planning, noise abatement, and compatibility programs. 4% of discretionary funds are reserved for converting military airports. Two-thirds of 1% of discretionary funds are set aside for reliever airports in metropolitan areas with flight delays. The Secretary of Transportation ensures that 75% of grants are used for airport capacity, safety, security, and noise compatibility planning. FAA must allocate $5 million for testing innovative aviation security systems from the remaining 25% of funds. The Secretary of Transportation has discretion in distributing grants from the discretionary fund for aviation security systems. Participating states receive block grants for projects at small airports, with responsibilities including project selection, funding, and compliance with federal priorities. States like Georgia, Illinois, Michigan, Missouri, and New participate in the state block grant program. The federal government shares for airport improvement projects vary depending on the type of airport. Participating states in the block grant program include Georgia, Illinois, Michigan, Missouri, New Hampshire, North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Texas, and Wisconsin. Large and medium hub airports receive a 75% federal share, while other airports receive a 90% federal share. Certain exceptions and transition periods may apply for specific airport projects. Communities receiving subsidized air service may be eligible for up to a 95% federal share of project costs, with smaller airports paying a lower share than larger airports. Smaller airports heavily rely on AIP grants to meet their capital needs, especially noncommercial airports. Grant applications require assurances for future airport operations, such as public availability without economic discrimination. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) requires airports to adhere to certain conditions to receive Airport Improvement Program (AIP) grants, including non-discriminatory public use, financial reporting, and expenditure of revenue on airport costs. These obligations extend beyond project completion and may last up to 20 years. Airports can request release from these obligations, but federal obligations for land purchased with AIP funds do not expire. Decisions on airport expansion projects funded by AIP grants have implications for reauthorization. Large runway projects can take 10+ years from concept to construction. Runway projects at large and medium hub airports are often funded in part by AIP funds. Airports may need AIP funding for projects required by 2025. Airport sponsors may need to use AIP discretionary funds for runway projects due to restrictions on passenger facility charges. If AIP budget is constrained in the future, large airports' capacity expansion projects may be limited. Congress could prioritize capacity enhancement at large and medium hub airports by shifting AIP funds. One option is to eliminate the requirement for large airports to forgo 75% of their entitlement, giving them a greater share of funding but reducing grants to small airports. Changes in discretionary fund set-asides could provide FAA more flexibility in fund usage. Statutory set-asides of discretionary funds could give FAA more flexibility to use money for capacity enhancement, potentially reducing funding for noise mitigation. The current AIP structure benefits smaller airports more than medium hub airports. Policy changes allowing airports to use entitlements more flexibly could benefit smaller airports but may conflict with reducing congestion at major airports. Allowing large and medium hub airports to opt out of the AIP and rely on PFCs could reduce trust fund revenue needed for the AIP. Large and medium hub airports could opt out of AIP and rely on PFCs for financing capital projects by raising or eliminating the federal cap on PFCs. This would release airports from some AIP grant assurances, potentially reducing AIP spending or redirecting funds to other airports. The PFC was introduced in 1990 as a user charge to supplement AIP funding. The Passenger Facility Charge (PFC) is a fee imposed on each paying passenger boarding an aircraft at airports. Initially capped at $3 per airport and $12 per round trip, the PFC is used to finance eligible airport projects and can also be used to service debt. In 2000, the PFC ceiling was raised to $4.50 with an $18 limit per round trip, requiring airports to demonstrate significant improvements in air safety, competition, or congestion reduction to exceed $3. The Passenger Facility Charge (PFC) is a fee imposed on each paying passenger boarding an aircraft at airports. Large and medium hub airports imposing PFCs above the $3 level forgo 75% of their AIP formula funds. PFCs at large and medium hub airports may not be approved unless the airport has submitted a written competition plan to FAA. The FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 made permanent the pilot program that authorized non-hub small airports to impose PFCs. The Passenger Facility Charge (PFC) is a fee imposed on each paying passenger boarding an aircraft at airports. PFC revenues are heavily used for landside projects such as terminals and transit systems on airport property, and for interest payments. Annual system-wide PFC collections grew from $85.4 million in 1992 to over $3 billion in 2016, with a broader interpretation of "capacity enhancing" projects compared to AIP funds. Air carriers must be notified and consulted about the use of PFC funds. The central legislative issue related to Passenger Facility Charges (PFCs) is whether to raise or eliminate the $4.50 per enplaned passenger ceiling. Airports argue for increasing or eliminating the ceiling, while air carriers and some passenger advocates oppose higher limits on PFCs. A GAO study in January 2015 showed that raising the cap would significantly increase PFC revenues. The GAO report suggests that raising the cap on Passenger Facility Charges (PFCs) would increase collections for airports but could slow passenger growth. Airport operators want more flexibility in using PFC funds for off-airport projects, while carriers are concerned about the use of funds for low-priority projects. Major carriers also seek more influence over project decisions. The Airport Privatization Pilot Program (APPP) was established in 1996 to explore privatizing publicly owned airports. Participation has been limited, with only two airports completing privatization. Lack of interest in privatization among U.S. airports may be due to decisions being made by local and state governments or public entities, rather than resident air carriers. Airport privatization in the United States is limited due to various factors such as readily available financing for publicly owned airports, barriers to privatization, implications for stakeholders, and satisfaction with the current system. Most cases of airport privatization in the US involve partial privatization, with full privatization being rare. This can include outsourcing noncore operations to private firms specializing in those functions. Outsourcing of noncore operations to private firms specializing in services such as cleaning, landscaping, shuttle bus operations, and concessions is common in U.S. airports. Management contracts are also utilized for specific facilities or responsibilities like parking, terminal concessions, and airfield signage. Developer financing and operation contracts involve the private sector in providing financing, development, operation, and maintenance services, known as the Design-Build-Finance-Operate-Maintain (DBFOM) model. The DBFOM model involves private sector financing, development, operation, and maintenance services for airport facilities like passenger terminals, parking garages, and rental car facilities. Full privatization can include long-term lease or sale of an airport to a private owner, granting management control in exchange for capital improvements and other obligations. Ownership and responsibility for operation can be transferred to a private buyer in a full sale. Airport privatization in the United States involves major stakeholders like airport owners, air carriers, private investors, and the federal government. Privatization can impact passengers through airport services, efficiency, and pricing. Local governments may see privatization as a revenue source, but federal regulations dictate how privatization revenue is used. Passenger interests are often not formally represented in privatization discussions. Federal regulations require that revenue from airport privatization be used for airport purposes, unless airlines agree otherwise. Privatization involves surrendering control of the airport, potentially leading to loss of public-sector jobs. The APPP grants exemptions to public-sector owners regarding revenue diversion. Air carriers aim to keep costs low and have control over airport revenues. Air carriers aim to keep costs low and control airport revenues. However, carriers also want well-maintained airports and may support privatization for lower charges and better services. Private investors seek financial returns and focus on growth potential, like increasing flights and improving amenities for additional lease revenue. The FAA is exploring private capital involvement in aviation infrastructure to reduce reliance on federal grants. Only one large hub commercial airport can join the program. The Airport Privatization Pilot Program (APPP) allows for the privatization of general aviation airports, with only one large hub commercial airport eligible for leasing. The program has seen limited success, with 11 airports applying and only two completing privatization. Westchester County Airport, NY, is the most recent applicant. The APPP has not generated widespread interest in airport privatization due to modest results. The Airport Privatization Pilot Program (APPP) allows for the privatization of airports, but the process is time-consuming and risky. The application process involves filing a preliminary application with the FAA, which can take years to complete. Once preliminary approval is received, the airport can select a private operator, negotiate an agreement, and submit a final application. FAA review of the final application has no set timeline. After FAA proposes approval in the Federal Register, there is a 60-day public review period. Airport privatization under the Airport Privatization Pilot Program (APPP) involves a lengthy process with regulatory requirements that may deter interest. These requirements include approval from 65% of air carriers, restrictions on rate increases exceeding CPI, and compliance with previous grant assurances. Post-privatization, the airport can receive AIP formula grants covering 70% of improvement costs, compared to the usual 75%-90% federal share for publicly owned airports. Privatizing an airport under the Airport Privatization Pilot Program (APPP) involves regulatory requirements that may discourage interest. Lack of resources is less of an issue for airport operators compared to highway and public transportation agencies. Publicly owned airports have access to various funding sources, including federal grants and passenger facility charges. Tax-exempt bonds secured by airport revenue offer cost-effective financing for airport projects. Tenant leases, landing fees, and state/local grants are also important revenue sources. Privatizing a publicly owned airport outside the APPP may result in the private operator facing challenges in accessing federal funds and issuing tax-exempt bonds. The private operator of an airport under the Airport Privatization Pilot Program (APPP) would have more freedom to impose fees and charges, but would need to provide a 30% match for federal grants. They cannot issue tax-exempt bonds and face limitations on raising fees for air carriers. Airport privatization in the United States has been less attractive due to federal laws, unlike in Europe and Canada where major airports were previously owned by national governments. The tax-favored status of debt issued by U.S. state and local governments also hinders privatization efforts. Congress is interested in privatization to reduce federal assistance dependency and increase aviation capacity. Streamlining the privatization process under the Airport Privatization Pilot Program (APPP) could make it more attractive, but structural changes to the airport financing system may be necessary to significantly increase interest in privatization. This could include offering the same tax treatment to private and public airport infrastructure bonds. The text discusses potential changes to airport financing to make privatization more attractive, such as extending tax benefits to private airport infrastructure bonds and reducing requirements for private operators to obtain grants. These changes could incentivize shifting airports from public to private ownership. Privatization of airports could be more appealing to investors with AIP funding. However, changes like selling airport property may conflict with federal interests in aviation system capacity and safety. Liberalizing fee rules, allowing more flexibility in imposing charges and fees, and easing limits on revenue use could stimulate privatization interest but may face airline opposition and potentially lead to higher costs for passengers and shippers. The National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) requires assessment of noise impacts on aviation infrastructure. Noise concerns have been contentious in airspace redesigns and airport expansion projects. Reductions in aircraft noise levels have been significant over the past 30 years, with a decline in residents exposed to significant noise. Louder Stage 2 airliners over 75,000 pounds have been phased out. The FAA has phased out louder Stage 2 airliners over 75,000 pounds and mandated quieter noise standards for all jet airplanes by 2015. New aircraft must meet Stage 4 noise standards, with plans for even stricter Stage 5 standards. Noise reduction achieved through engine technology, lightweight materials, and aerodynamics. Collaboration with NASA and industry on quiet aircraft technologies. Despite quieter aircraft, air traffic volume has increased around major airports in the past 30 years. There are proposals to grant the FAA flexibility to fund noise mitigation projects in areas with lower noise levels, but this could divert resources from capacity and safety projects. NextGen is a modernization of air traffic technologies and procedures to expand airspace capacity. NextGen is a multiyear initiative to modernize the national airspace system by using satellite-based navigation and aircraft tracking. It aims to reduce air traffic separation, improve airspace utilization, and minimize environmental impacts. The system targets full implementation by 2025. The FAA established the Joint Planning and Development Office (JPDO) to develop and implement the Next Generation Air Transportation System (NextGen) by 2025. The JPDO released the Integration National Plan for NextGen in 2004, aiming to improve air transportation safety, security, mobility, efficiency, and capacity. Failure to implement NextGen could lead to increased air travel congestion and costs. The FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 refined and expanded NextGen implementation, establishing the Chief NextGen Officer position and requiring annual progress reports to Congress. It also directed reviews of ADS-B ground system installation and enterprise architecture for NextGen, aiming to accelerate deployment of technologies and procedures. The FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 directed FAA to accelerate NextGen technologies and procedures deployment, track national airspace performance metrics, evaluate airport surveillance technologies, establish a NextGen research center, and promote public-private partnerships for NextGen avionics equipage. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2014 defunded the JPDO and directed FAA to absorb its functions into NextGen operations planning. The FAA Modernization and Reform Act of 2012 directed FAA to accelerate NextGen technologies and procedures deployment. In May 2014, FAA moved the JPDO functions into a newly created NextGen Interagency Planning Office. NextGen is described as a significant effort of cross-boundary transformation by integrating air traffic control infrastructure with cockpit instrumentation. Cargo airlines played a key role in developing core NextGen technological concepts in the 1990s. Cargo airlines, including UPS, played a significant role in developing core NextGen cockpit technologies in the 1990s. UPS received recognition for its development of ADS-B technology, which is now a key component of the NextGen system. UPS Aviation Technologies, later acquired by Garmin Ltd., contributed to the advancement of ADS-B avionics and GPS navigation devices. Garmin has become a major supplier of ADS-B equipment and advanced avionics in the aviation industry. In 1999, FAA started the Capstone Program in Alaska to test GPS, ADS-B, and advanced avionics for general aviation safety. This program laid the foundation for the NextGen initiative. In 2001, FAA established the Operational Evolution Plan to address future capacity needs in the aviation system. The Operational Evolution Plan (OEP) proposed technology solutions for future capacity requirements in the nation's busiest airports and airspace, including RNAV procedures, WAAS, controller-pilot data link technologies, and reduced vertical separation. These components later became part of the NextGen initiative, which aims to provide increased operating flexibilities and efficiency in air traffic control. The NextGen initiative aims to modernize air traffic control by replacing radar with satellite-based GPS for aircraft tracking. It receives over $1 billion annually in funding through the FAA's Facilities and Equipment account. Key components include Automatic Dependent Surveillance - Broadcast (ADS-B) for transmitting and receiving aircraft data. The FAA funds the installation, operation, and maintenance of a ground network to receive ADS-B transmissions and relay them to air traffic facilities and aircraft. NextGen technologies include telephone capabilities for aircraft communication, CATMT for automation tools, NVS for digital voice communications, and NextGen Weather for weather information. WAAS was developed by the FAA in 1995 and allows aircraft to fly instrument approaches using GPS for lateral and vertical guidance. FAA is consolidating air traffic facilities to control costs, replace outdated facilities, and improve services, primarily focusing on TRACON facilities in major metropolitan areas. FAA is consolidating air traffic facilities by decoupling combined airport tower/approach control facilities and merging approach control functions across larger areas. Outdated combined tower/TRACON facilities are being replaced with towers only, while TRACON components are relocated to consolidated facilities.
